Happy Holidays from Alloy

Over the past year, our team has grown so much! We’ve added four new team members and landed exciting new clients. This holiday season, we’re celebrating how the holidays look different in every household. Each Alloy team member has shared the favorite festive dish that they’re looking forward to making (or consuming) over the holidays. Enjoy!

Anna


Cook

Grandma Otte’s Texas Sheet Cake

I come from a farming community in Alva, Oklahoma. With our farm in the family for more than 100 years, we celebrate tradition, family and good harvests. Our holidays are filled with lots of simple and shareable comfort foods. There are so many that I love — fried chicken, dilly bread, chocolate fudge, and so on — but this Texas sheet cake was special because my great grandma, Dorothy Otte, would make it. Here’s to her!

Ingredients

  • 1 cup Miracle Whip mayonnaise
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 1 cup boiling water
  • 2 cups flour
  • 4 tbsp cocoa
  • 1 ½ tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp vanilla

For Frosting

  • 1 stick butter
  • 4 tbsp cocoa
  • 6 tbsp milk
  • 1 box powdered sugar
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 2/3 cups chopped walnuts

Directions

  1. Grease and flour a large cookie sheet, place aside for later
  2. Mix flour, cocoa, and baking soda together in bowl
  3. Mix mayonnaise, sugar, and boiling water together separately from dry ingredients
  4. Once both items have been mixed, blend them all together quickly
  5. Pour mixture into cookie sheet
  6. Carefully place in oven, mixture can spill easily
  7. Bake at 350º F (175º C) for about 30 minutes
  1. For frosting bring to boil: butter, cocoa, and milk
  2. Remove from heat and add: powdered sugar, vanilla, and chopped walnuts
  3. Spread on hot cake

Share

David


Millsaps

Mike’s Dump Cake

In my family, cooking is an art form and an expression of love. We are big on old traditions and local ingredients. Everyone is a decent cook. One of our close friends, who is also an excellent cook, introduced this recipe to me. It stands in stark contrast to those values, but it goes so well with traditional southern holiday dishes and it's easy. A great potluck addition — guests always love it, and my wife is always ashamed to serve it.

Ingredients

  • 1 (21 oz) can cherry pie filling
  • 1 (15 oz) can crushed pineapple
  • 1 (18.25 oz) package yellow cake mix
  • 1/2 stick margarine
  • 1/2 stick butter

Directions

  1. Mix cherries and pineapple in a 9x13 inch pan
  2. Evenly sprinkle dry cake mix over fruit mixture
  3. Evenly distribute slices of butter and margarine across cake mix
  4. Bake in a 350º F (175º C) oven for 45 to 50 minutes or until golden brown

Share

Derek


Adams

My Go-To “Were We Supposed to Bring Something?” Cupcakes

My family has never really had any secret recipes. They live in the Midwest and on the years when I do make it out there, my wife and I need a recipe that can be put together in situ and doesn't require a lot of kitchen space or time. This recipe isn't just for holidays, either — it can be used for any gathering you're invited to without much warning. As an added bonus, these cupcakes can be made vegan!

Ingredients

  • 1 (18.25 oz) package yellow cake mix
  • 1 (15 oz) can of pumpkin (not pumpkin pie filling)
  • Powdered sugar (optional)
  • Milk (optional)

Directions

  1. Mix the cake mix and canned pumpkin
  2. Distribute portions of mixture into a muffin tin
  3. Bake at 325º F (163º C) for 19 minutes
  4. Give them 10 minutes to cool
  5. Mix milk with powdered sugar in a bowl until thickened
  6. Dip the cupcakes for a frosting glaze

Share

Hannah


Suttle

My Great Grandmother’s Mincemeat Pie

For my parents, mince pies are filled with memories of childhood. My great grandmother, who made the best pastry in all of England, would bake dozens of them and they were just little bundles of celebration! They are as central to Christmas in England as Santa and jingle bells.

Ingredients

  • 12 oz all-purpose flour/plain flour
  • Pinch of salt
  • 8 oz of butter
  • 1 egg
  • 1 jar of mincemeat

Directions

  1. Heat the oven to 400º F (205º C)
  2. Mix flour, butter and salt in a bowl or food processor until it has a sandy texture
  3. Whisk an egg and add it to the mixture
  4. Add cold water (as needed) until the mixture binds but is not sticky
  5. Place the dough in the fridge to chill for 15-30 minutes
  6. Dust the counter with flour and roll out two-thirds of the pastry until it is about ⅛-inch thick
  7. Use a small pie or circular cookie cutter to cut the dough to fit in a muffin tray
  8. Place the dough into the tray and fill each of the cups about 2/3 with mincemeat
  9. Roll out the rest of the pastry and cut to the same thickness, but smaller circles to make tops for the pies (you can also cut them into stars or other holiday shapes)
  10. Line the edges of the tops with water and press them onto the pies
  11. Poke a small hole or two in the top of each pie
  12. Bake in the oven for about 20 minutes (or until they have a golden-brown color)

Share

Henry


Desroches

Caraway & Maple Brussels Sprouts

This recipe entered our holiday traditions when I was about 8. I wish I could say it was passed down for generations — but no, my dad found it in a book. In our house, the formal holiday meal was on Christmas Eve, which my dad was in charge of. My mom's not a huge fan of the kitchen, but she's a master at putting Butter Braids in the oven for Christmas breakfast. 🙄

Ingredients

  • 1 1/2 tbsp unsalted butter, divided
  • 1 1/2 tsp olive oil
  • 1 tbsp chopped fresh thyme
  • 2 tsps caraway seeds
  • 1 lb brussels sprouts, trimmed and halved
  • 2 cups thinly vertically sliced onion (about 1 large onion)
  • 6 garlic cloves, thinly sliced
  • 1/4 cup pure maple syrup
  • 3 tbsp sherry vinegar
  • 1 tsp dijon mustard
  • 1/2 tsp kosher salt
  • 1/2 tsp black pepper

Directions

  1. Heat 1 1/2 teaspoons butter, oil, thyme, and caraway in a large non-stick skillet over medium-low, swirling until butter melts
  2. Cook 2 to 3 minutes or until butter starts to foam
  3. Increase heat to medium-high and add Brussels sprouts to pan
  4. Cook 6 to 7 minutes or until browned and crisp-tender
  5. Remove from pan, then add onion and garlic to pan; sauté for 6 minutes
  6. Return brussels sprouts to pan
  7. Stir in syrup, vinegar, mustard, and salt and cook for 2 minutes
  8. Remove pan from heat and stir in remaining 1 tablespoon butter and pepper

Share

Kerri


Howell

North Carolina White Sweet Potato Pie

This recipe represents my first contribution to my family's holiday traditions. One year my grandparents gave me a few white sweet potatoes from their garden and asked me to do something with them — so I baked a pie. Now they ask me to bring one to Thanksgiving and Christmas every year.

Ingredients

  • 1 stick of margarine
  • 2 cups sugar
  • 2 eggs
  • 2 heaping tbsps flour
  • 2-3 tsps vanilla or to taste
  • Cinnamon to taste
  • Allspice to taste
  • 1 cup of white sweet potatoes: you can find these at a farmer's market or grow them at home, but you won't find them in a grocery store

Directions

  1. Boil and mash white sweet potatoes.
  2. Melt 1 stick of margarine in bowl.
  3. Add sugar and eggs, and mix together until creamy (best done with an electric mixer).
  4. Add 2 heaping tbsp of flour, 1 cup of white sweet potatoes<./li>
  5. Add 2 or 3 tsps of vanilla, cinnamon and allspice to taste, and mix together.
  6. Pour into a pie crust and bake in a 350º F (175º C) oven. Bake until pie firms and is golden brown or looks done.

Share

Kristie


Wallis

Nana's Hungarian Kiffles

I grew up making these cookies with my mom and grandmother every Christmas. My Nana's Hungarian cookies were her signature dish. As soon as an uncle or another family member received them, others were at her doorstep saying, “I heard you made some cookies.” As my mom says, they're like potato chips. You can't just eat one!

Ingredients

  • 3 cups flour
  • Pinch of salt
  • 3 tsps baking powder
  • 1/2 cup sugar
  • 1/2 lb butter or margarine
  • 1 tbsp Crisco
  • 3 egg yolks
  • 1/2 pint of sour cream
  • Solo pie filling (apricot is the favorite, but it's fun to mix the batch with different flavors)
  • Powdered sugar

Directions

  1. Sift flour, salt, baking powder and sugar
  2. Add margarine, Crisco, egg yolks and sour cream
  3. Chill 1/2 hour
  4. Flour table or board for better rolling
  5. Roll dough out and cut with floured cookie cutter (triangled one preferred)
  6. Fill with solo filling in a can
  7. Fold over edges, press down a little so they don't open
  8. Bake at 350º F (175º C) for 20-30 minutes, or until brown at the edges
  9. When done, sprinkle cookies with powdered sugar

Share

Matt


Moen

Mom's Sausage Stuffing

In our family, there was one dish that got attached to a person — Grandma's stuffing. I don't know where it originally came from. It may have been passed down for generations, or she may have pulled it from a Betty Crocker book in the 60's. Either way, it's important to note that it has sausage — and so it's amazing — and that since she passed everyone in the family competes to see who can make the most authentic version. This version comes from my mom.

Ingredients

  • 1 onion chopped
  • 1 lb breakfast sausage meat crumbled (or Jimmy Dean's vegan sausage)
  • 2 1/2 sleeves saltine crackers
  • Salt and pepper to taste
  • Milk
  • Turkey gravy (optional)

Directions

  1. Chop onion and saute/brown
  2. In same frying pan, saute/brown crumbled sausage
  3. Let cook
  4. Crumble saltine crackers and combine in bowl with sausage/onion mixture
  5. (Best to combine with hands, squishing it all together)
  6. Add salt and pepper to taste
  7. Add milk to moisten
  8. Add turkey gravy for bolder flavor
  9. Ensure the mixture to sticks together
  10. Bake 30-40 minutes at 325º F (163º C)

Share

Megan


Kilpatrick

My Scottish Grandmother’s Baked Apples

Growing up, most holidays were spent at my grandparents' house in Black Mountain, NC — the Kilpatrick side of the family. One of my grandfather's favorite desserts was Scottish Baked Apples. I think Grandmother was especially happy to make them because they were much healthier than many of his other favorite foods and beverages. The smell of baked apples still has the power to transport me to those wonderful days in the mountains. (And yes, I actually called them “Grandmother” and “Grandfather.”)

Ingredients

  • 6 cooking apples — Golden Delicious apples work great
  • 3 handfuls of raisins
  • 3 tbsps of oats
  • 6 tsps of honey

Directions

  1. Pre-heat the oven to 375º F (190 degree C).
  2. Cut out the apple cores and arrange the apples in a baking dish (high edges help!). Pour in just enough cold water to cover the bottom of the baking dish.
  3. Mix the raisins, oats and honey in a bowl. Fill the empty core of each apple with the oat mush. Pack it full.
  4. Bake for 40 minutes. Get ready for a delicious-smelling house!
  5. Let the apples sit for a few minutes after you take them out of the oven. Serve each apple in its own cereal bowl while they're still hot, and top with healthy scoops of vanilla ice cream. Eat with a spoon!

Share

Sarah


Shelness

Traditional Japanese Garlic Edamame

Edamame wasn't available in grocery stores when my mom was growing up, so my grandparents grew soybean plants in their backyard garden. When it was time to pick the pods, my grandparents would dig up the whole plant and have my mom and her siblings pick the pods off the plant at the kitchen table. Now, it's pretty easy to find bags of frozen edamame for a quick snack or appetizer. We'll usually eat them steamed and salted, but it's fun to add extra flavor for special occasions like the holidays!

Ingredients

  • 2 lbs of soybeans in pods
  • Compound butter (combine all ingredients together)
    • 1/2 cup butter, at room temperature
    • 1 tbsp minced garlic
    • 1 tsp minced shallots
    • 1/4 tsp Worcestershire sauce
    • 1/4 tsp hot pepper sauce
    • 1 tbsp lemon juice
    • Pinch parsley
  • 2 tbsps olive oil
  • 6 cloves garlic, minced
  • Lemon wedge

Directions

  1. Boil or microwave soybean pods until tender
  2. Melt compound butter in large skillet over medium heat
  3. Add olive oil and garlic
  4. Saute until garlic begins to brown
  5. Turn off heat and add soy beans, toss to coat
  6. Finish with a squeeze of lemon

Share

Stephon


Beaufort

New Orleans Okra Succotash

This recipe was passed down from my grandma. It's a Cajun-style dish that’s easy to prepare. This hearty meal can be easily shared with your family and loved ones, and it tastes better a day after it’s made

Ingredients

  • 2 lbs fresh or frozen okra trimmed and cut into pieces
  • 2 large yellow onions, finely chopped
  • 3 bay leaves
  • 1 lb smoked pork sausage cut into slices
  • 1 lb boneless smoked ham cut into cubes
  • Salt
  • Cajun seasoning
  • Cooked rice
  • 1 can crushed tomatoes (optional)

Directions

  1. Generously coat heavy skillet or sauce pan with olive oil or cooking oil.
  2. Over a medium heat add okra. Cook okra uncovered until tender and no white color is present. Stir continuously.
  3. Add more oil as needed.
  4. Add onions. Cook until tender.
  5. Add smoked ham and pork sausage.
  6. Add desired portion of Cajun seasoning and salt to taste.
  7. Add Bay leaves.
  8. Optionally, add 1 can of crushed tomatoes.
  9. Let simmer covered for 45 minutes.
  10. Add shrimp. Cook additional 15 minutes.
  11. Serve over cooked rice.

Share
